comment.author: 22591772@N05
comment._content:
I have pictures of my father who served in the Navy in WW1.  His cap has 
HMS President on it even though he didn't serve on the vessel.  Why is this?

comment.author: 25252126@N08
comment._content: Congratulations, E x c e l l e n t!

comment.author: 22591772@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] No, I have a photo of a group of men in naval uniform all with HMS President on their caps - I have always presumed it was taken during a wireless operators course.

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/still_base] 
Hi Stillbase,

According to my information this HMS 'President' was used as the drill ship of the Royal Naval Reserve in South West India Docks in 1862 and was sold for breaking up in 1903. 

Was your father a member of the Royal Naval Reserve Volunteers London Division who named many of their drill bases HMS 'President'?

Lucinda

comment.author: 22591772@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalmaritimemuseum] Many thanks for the reply.  He was a member of the RNVR and trained at Chatham and your comment above would probably explain why we have several photos with him wearing that cap.

comment.author: 13675154@N04
comment._content:
Interesting picture,  Wikipedia says she was a "52-gun fourth-rate launched in 1829"
It looks like a regular sailing ship of that time but later converted by removing the masts  building side walls and roof to enclose the deck area. And building over the old bow spirit in the front. Am I correct?

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13675154@N04] 
Hi oakbluffcamper

You are correct HMS President was a 52-gun Fourth Rate Frigate launched in 1829 at Portsmouth Dockyardn and was altered to suit being a static training ship byt the addition of walls and a roof.

Lucinda

comment.author: 31181068@N05
comment._content: Is it possible that she was a prison hulk at one time ?
